block.p: ''Capturing Every Moment of That Saturday Soccer Match'' (Sept. 21) concludes by essentially saying that creating movies with iMovie software is a nice thing to do but may take too much time.
''Capturing Every Moment of That Saturday Soccer Match'' (Sept. 21) concludes by essentially saying that creating movies with iMovie software is a nice thing to do but may take too much time.

I would ask the writer if he ever becomes a chef at home and takes four or five hours of time to prepare a delicious meal and then present it in a beautiful fashion to his loved ones or friends. Millions of people do. And similarly, I'm positive millions of home editors will take the time to prepare a visual feast for those they care about.

As someone immersed in making iMovies of his economics lectures at Baruch College of the City University of New York, as well as someone who is a home chef (so far a better chef than editor), I see these two activities as remarkably similar.
Both require planning, coordination, technical expertise, patience, time and an eye for detail.

The only difference is that I usually don't have to come up with a catchy title for a meal. That's not true for my current iMovie. I can't decide between ''Napster -- Blackbeard or Robin Hood?'' ''Napster Is Adam Smith's Invisible Hand'' or ''Napster: It's Not a Problem; It's a Blessing.''
